item.title: Computational + Behavioral Economics
item.description:
I’m teaching a class on computational, behavioral economics. Details are below; signup link is here

tl/dr

  • Class: Learn behavioral economics using math and code. Model and implement an economic/social situation you’re interested in.
  • Time: Tuesdays 7-9PM.
  • Duration: 7 weeks, from 1.20.26 to 3.3.26 (skipping 2.17.26)
  • Location: Lower Manhattan (in-person only)
  • Cost: $120 (scholarship), $210 (standard), $300 (supporter). Send me an email if none of these work.

Summary

Over 7 weeks, we’re going to use modern machinery (math and code) to explore behavioral economics. By the end, you’ll have written a small interactive paper1 where you apply these tools to a problem you’re interested in.

item.title: hikes
item.description:
Some notes on hikes and backcountry situations.

  • Chinatown to Chinatown to Chinatown Walk (11/25, NY): Not technically a hike, but a 20 mile Friendsgiving walk from Manhattan Chinatown to 8th Ave. Brooklyn to Flushing. Took breaks about every 3 miles on the second leg, near parks and coffeeshops. Nonlinear difference between this and the 32 mile perimeter one; this was quite manageable, but 32 mile one was disabling by the end. Got hotpot at the end.

item.title: links
item.description:
Some things I think are worth sharing.

  • Scientific American: North American bird populations have declined 29% since 1970.
  • NPR: As recently as 1960, fish used to be huge.
  • Green Your Lab: Good people working on sustainable science.
  • WIPP: How to warn people 10000 years from now about radioactive waste.
  • Sylvia Jacobson: Was confined to a skyjacked plane for a week, and wrote a paper about it.
  • Ken Liu: State Change (short story).
  • 129 Cars: This American Life (WBEZ Chicago) spends a month at a car dealership.
  • The Glass Room: A digital art exhibit by Mozilla, focused on examining issues of data and privacy.
  • Panopticlick: An EFF tool that lets you see how “unique” your browser’s fingerprint is.
  • Tor: An easy-to-use version of Firefox that effectively anonymizes your internet traffic.
  • The MIT License, Line by Line: /dev/lawyer does a close-reading of the common MIT License.
  • Kalle Lasn: “Cleaning Up the Mental Environment.” Lasn is the founder/publisher of Vancouver-based Adbusters.
  • Wipr: Highly effective macOS adblocker. I use this.
  • Gather.Town: 8bit online spaces. I invested in this.
  • Concentration of Measure. People use this word and we should know what it means. It’s more than Hoeffding or DKW or something. Bobkov’s inequality looks profound but above my level.
  • Surviving First Year. Good advice.
  • Multivariate Delta Method + Glivenko-Cantelli Classes. I worked with GC classes for a year but it never sunk in until I saw section 8.4.
